Title: Projection map being a closed map
Content: Let $\pi: X \times Y \to X$ be the projection map where $Y$ is compact. Prove that $\pi$ is a closed map. First I would like to see a proof of this claim. I want to know that here why compactness is necessary or do we have any other weaker condition other than compactness for the same result to hold.
AcceptedAnswer: There is a standard example for why some hypothesis on $Y$ is necessary: let $X=Y=\mathbb R$ , and consider the closed subset $F=\{(x,y)\in \mathbb R\times\mathbb R:xy=1\}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^2$ . What is its projection to the first factor? In fact, one can prove that a space $Y$ is compact iff for all spaces $X$ the projection $X\times Y\to X$ is closed. So while compactness is not necessary (I think...) for the closedness of the projection for one $X$ , it is necessary if you want all such projections to be closed. As for the proof you want in the first bullet point... this is a standard exercise in topology: what have you tried?

Proof: True
proof:
Problem:
Given that Y is a compact topological space and X is any topological space, prove that the projection map π: X × Y → X is a closed map.

Solution:
Let C be a closed subset of the product space X × Y. To prove that π is a closed map, we must show that its image, π(C), is a closed subset of X.

We will prove this by showing that the complement of π(C), denoted by X \ π(C), is an open set.

Let x be an arbitrary point in X \ π(C). By definition, this means that x is not in the image of C under π. This implies that there is no point y ∈ Y such that (x, y) ∈ C. In other words, the set {x} × Y is disjoint from C, i.e., ({x} × Y) ∩ C = ∅.

Now, consider the set {x} × Y. This set, as a subspace of X × Y, is homeomorphic to Y. Since Y is given to be a compact space, {x} × Y is also a compact set.

We have a compact set K = {x} × Y and a closed set C in the space X × Y such that K ∩ C = ∅. We will use this to find an open neighborhood of x that is disjoint from π(C).

For each point y ∈ Y, the point (x, y) is in K and therefore not in C. Since C is closed, its complement (X × Y) \ C is open. Thus, for each y ∈ Y, there exists a basic open neighborhood of (x, y), of the form U_y × V_y (where U_y is an open neighborhood of x in X and V_y is an open neighborhood of y in Y), such that (U_y × V_y) ∩ C = ∅.

The collection of sets {V_y | y ∈ Y} forms an open cover of the compact space Y. By the definition of compactness, there exists a finite subcover, say {V_{y_1}, V_{y_2}, ..., V_{y_n}}, that also covers Y.

Let U be the intersection of the corresponding open sets in X: U = U_{y_1} ∩ U_{y_2} ∩ ... ∩ U_{y_n}. Since this is a finite intersection of open sets containing x, U is an open neighborhood of x.

Now, consider the "tube" U × Y. We claim that (U × Y) ∩ C = ∅. To see this, let (x', y') be any point in U × Y. Then x' ∈ U and y' ∈ Y. Since {V_{y_i}} is a cover for Y, y' must belong to some V_{y_k} for k ∈ {1, ..., n}. By construction of U, x' ∈ U_{y_k}. Therefore, (x', y') ∈ U_{y_k} × V_{y_k}. But we know that U_{y_k} × V_{y_k} is disjoint from C. Thus, (x', y') cannot be in C. Since (x', y') was an arbitrary point in U × Y, it follows that U × Y is disjoint from C.

Finally, since (U × Y) ∩ C = ∅, it means there is no point (u, y) in C where u ∈ U. This is equivalent to saying that π(C) contains no points from U, i.e., U ∩ π(C) = ∅.

So, for an arbitrary point x ∈ X \ π(C), we have found an open neighborhood U of x such that U ⊂ X \ π(C). This proves that X \ π(C) is an open set. Consequently, its complement, π(C), is a closed set in X.

Since C was an arbitrary closed set in X × Y, we conclude that the projection map π is a closed map.
